Here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro's ExtendScript JavaScript API for timeline manipulation:

## Overview

Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application. ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.(no content)Adobe ExtendScript is a JavaScript-based scripting language that allows developers to automate tasks in Premiere Pro. By leveraging ExtendScript, editors can automate video editing workflows, reduce manual work, and improve efficiency.

## Current Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

## Timeline Manipulation Capabilities

The API provides various timeline manipulation features:

- New API to move a trackItem. New APIs to set the disabled state of a trackItem.
- You can automatically insert video clips into a sequence using ExtendScript.
- You can automate clip trimming to quickly edit multiple clips. Scripts can select all clips in the first video track and trim the first 5 seconds from each clip.

## Limitations

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. However, this is disputed - there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and the `moveToTrack()` function may still work.(no content)There is no single ExtendScript call to split a clip based on playhead position, though workarounds may be possible.

## Resources & Documentation

- The PProPanel example extension (https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel), while very ugly, is thorough in demonstrating PPro's ExtendScript API. The project contains VSCode debugging configurations for JavaScript (the CEP layer) and ExtendScript.

- Executing scripts from within CEP panels is the recommended approach. With additional configuration work, it's also possible to pass scripts to Premiere Pro on a command line.

- Use VSCode with Adobe's extension for development and debugging; for deployed workflows, stick with panels whenever possible.

The main documentation is available at: https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Adobe Premiere Pro SDK plugin development for 2024-2025:

## Adobe Premiere Pro SDK Plugin Development Guide (2024-2025)

### Official Resources

The Adobe Premiere Pro Software Development Kit is a living document that is constantly being updated and edited. The latest release of the SDK is available at: https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html.(no content)The Premiere Pro APIs allow you to seamlessly connect tools in your workflow, automate complex tasks, communicate with external hardware, and add support for new file formats and codecs.

### Types of Plugins You Can Develop

The Premiere Pro SDK allows developers to interact with video editing workflows, media files, and UI elements inside Premiere Pro. Plugin types include:
- Panel Plugins (UXP/CEP Extensions) – Custom UI panels for automation
- Video Effects Plugins – Custom filters, LUTs, and overlays
- Transition Plugins – Custom wipe, dissolve, and animation transitions
- Audio Effects Plugins – EQ, noise reduction, and AI-powered enhancements
- File Import & Export Automation – Batch processing for video files

### Development Approaches

**1. C++ SDK Development**
The Premiere Pro Software Development Kit enables developers to create plugins for Premiere Pro, After Effects, Audition, Media Encoder, Character Animator, and Premiere Elements. The required development environment for Windows is Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 Update 3 on Windows 11.(no content)The C++ SDK is complete, and used without issue by C++ plugin developers. The C++ SDK does not contain any CEP or UXP resources.(no content)Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK — They may need the Premiere Pro headers.

**2. CEP Extensions (Common Extensibility Platform)**
CEP Extensions are built using HTML, JavaScript, and CSS for UI-based plugins.(no content)Adobe CEP is a framework that allows developers to create HTML5-based extensions for Adobe Creative Cloud applications. These extensions can be created using web technologies such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and can be used to add new features and tools to the software. CEP is designed to be easy to use and understand, even for developers with little or no experience with Adobe's Creative Cloud applications.

**3. UXP (New Development Platform)**
For any new development, it's recommended to investigate whether what you want to do is already possible via UXP, before starting a new CEP+ExtendScript-based extension.

### Development Environment

Per the PProPanel readme, Microsoft Visual Studio Code + the ExtendScript Debugger extension are the supported development environment.

### Current Premiere Pro Versions (2024-2025)

Recent Premiere Pro versions include Adobe Premiere Pro 24.6, 25.0, 25.1, 25.2, 25.3, and 25.4.

### Key Resources

1. **Official Developer Portal**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/
2. **C++ SDK Guide**: https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/
3. **GitHub Repository**: The Premiere Pro C++ SDK Guide is available on GitHub at docsforadobe/premiere-plugin-guide where you can contribute to development.
4. If you have questions about the APIs, your question may already be answered on the Premiere Pro SDK forum at: https://community.adobe.com/t5/forums/filteredbylabelpage/board-id/premiere-pro/label-name/sdk.

### Industry Statistics

According to a 2024 industry survey, 65% of video editors reported that using custom Premiere Pro plugins improved their workflow efficiency by at least 30%.(no content)According to Adobe's 2024 Digital Creativity Report, over 60% of video editors say that automation tools have helped them save at least 40% of their editing time.

**CEP (Common Extensibility Platform):**
- CEP has been Adobe's traditional method for building panels/extensions across Creative Cloud apps
- Uses HTML, CSS, and JavaScript with ExtendScript for app communication
- Works across multiple Adobe applications

**UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform):**
- UXP is Adobe's newer extensibility platform, designed to replace CEP
- Offers better performance and modern JavaScript APIs
- Already available in Photoshop and other apps
- Adobe has been gradually rolling out UXP support to more applications

Web search error: unavailable

I apologize, but I'm currently unable to perform a web search as the search tool is temporarily unavailable. 

However, I can share some general knowledge about Adobe Premiere Pro plugin distribution requirements:

1. **Code Signing**: Adobe typically requires plugins to be properly code-signed with valid developer certificates. For macOS, this means using an Apple Developer ID certificate, and for Windows, a code signing certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority.

2. **Adobe Exchange**: If you want to distribute through Adobe's official marketplace (Adobe Exchange), you'll need to:
   - Register as a developer
   - Meet their technical requirements
   - Pass their review process
   - Follow their branding guidelines

3. **CEP Extensions vs. Native Plugins**: The requirements differ depending on whether you're creating:
   - CEP (Common Extensibility Platform) panels using HTML/JavaScript
   - Native C++ plugins using the Adobe SDK

4. **Notarization (macOS)**: For macOS distribution, Apple requires notarization of software for it to run without security warnings on recent macOS versions.

For the most up-to-date and specific 2024 requirements, I'd recommend:
- Checking Adobe's official developer documentation at [adobe.io](https://developer.adobe.com)
- Reviewing the Adobe Exchange Partner Portal
- Consulting Adobe's Plugin SDK documentation

**Adobe Premiere Pro Plugin Development:**

1. **UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform)** - Adobe has been transitioning its creative apps to UXP, which uses modern web technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript). UXP has already been implemented in Photoshop and is being rolled out to other Adobe applications.

2. **CEP (Common Extensibility Platform)** - This was the previous extension framework using CEP panels built with HTML/CSS/JavaScript. Many existing Premiere Pro extensions still use CEP.

3. **ExtendScript** - The legacy scripting language for Adobe apps, which is being phased out in favor of UXP.

4. **Premiere Pro API** - Premiere Pro has its own scripting API for automation and integration.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Adobe Premiere Pro SDK for importing/exporting media metadata via API:

## Key Findings

### SDK Resources
The Premiere Pro C++ SDK documentation is a living document that is constantly being updated and edited. The latest release of the SDK is available at https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html.(no content)If you have questions about the APIs described in the SDK documentation, or about integration with Premiere Pro, your question may already be answered on the Premiere Pro SDK forum at https://community.adobe.com/t5/forums/filteredbylabelpage/board-id/premiere-pro/label-name/sdk.

### Metadata API Capabilities

PProPanel shows how to get and change metadata at the media (per clip) and sequence level.(no content)It is also possible to get/set private (per projectItem) metadata through the Adobe-CEP samples repository.(no content)Getting/setting the private project metadata is only possible from within Premiere Pro, not Bridge (which is limited to media-specific metadata).

### Limitations on Export Metadata

Adobe Media Encoder (AME) offers no APIs for manipulation of anything about, or within, a sequence.(no content)Typically, your extension would be at the mercy of the metadata output settings in effect when the export was triggered. One workaround approach is that upon successful programmatic export, your extension will be given the file path to the output media.(no content)Upon successful programmatic export, your extension will be given the file path to the output media. Your extension could then import that media into the project, set whatever XMP metadata you like, save the project (to flush the cached metadata to disk), then delete the media from the project.

### XMP Metadata in Premiere Pro

Adobe applications store metadata using the Extensible Metadata Platform (XMP). XMP is built on XML, which facilitates the exchange of metadata across a variety of applications and publishing workflows. Metadata in most other formats (such as Exif, GPS, and TIFF) automatically transfers to XMP.(no content)Use the XMP metadata fields to store data that applies to the source file, and all clip instances that point to it. Use the clip metadata fields to store data specific to each unique clip. Link clip metadata fields to XMP metadata fields when you want clip metadata copied to the source file.

### Developer Portal

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Adobe Premiere Pro SDK for importing/exporting media metadata via API:

## Key Findings

### SDK Resources
The Premiere Pro C++ SDK documentation is a living document that is constantly being updated and edited. The latest release of the SDK is available at https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html.(no content)If you have questions about the APIs described in the SDK documentation, or about integration with Premiere Pro, your question may already be answered on the Premiere Pro SDK forum at https://community.adobe.com/t5/forums/filteredbylabelpage/board-id/premiere-pro/label-name/sdk.

### Metadata API Capabilities

PProPanel shows how to get and change metadata at the media (per clip) and sequence level.(no content)It is also possible to get/set private (per projectItem) metadata through the Adobe-CEP samples repository.(no content)Getting/setting the private project metadata is only possible from within Premiere Pro, not Bridge (which is limited to media-specific metadata).

### Limitations on Export Metadata

Adobe Media Encoder (AME) offers no APIs for manipulation of anything about, or within, a sequence.(no content)Typically, your extension would be at the mercy of the metadata output settings in effect when the export was triggered. One workaround approach is that upon successful programmatic export, your extension will be given the file path to the output media.(no content)Upon successful programmatic export, your extension will be given the file path to the output media. Your extension could then import that media into the project, set whatever XMP metadata you like, save the project (to flush the cached metadata to disk), then delete the media from the project.

### XMP Metadata in Premiere Pro

Adobe applications store metadata using the Extensible Metadata Platform (XMP). XMP is built on XML, which facilitates the exchange of metadata across a variety of applications and publishing workflows. Metadata in most other formats (such as Exif, GPS, and TIFF) automatically transfers to XMP.(no content)Use the XMP metadata fields to store data that applies to the source file, and all clip instances that point to it. Use the clip metadata fields to store data specific to each unique clip. Link clip metadata fields to XMP metadata fields when you want clip metadata copied to the source file.

### Developer Portal
If you get "Restricted Access" when trying to download the C++ SDK and documentation, try logging in with a Personal account. The official developer portal is at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/.

content.content:
# Premiere Pro Plugin Development Overview

## Available Development Approaches

The platform supports three distinct plugin development methodologies:

**UXP Plugins** - The modern standard for Premiere v25.6 and beyond, described as "Build performant plugins with modern HTML, CSS, and JavaScript." This represents Adobe's next-generation API architecture.

**C++ SDK** - For developers requiring deeper system integration, enabling "powerful, low-level integrations using C++." The documentation accompanies the SDK download.

**CEP Panels** - The legacy extension framework using "HTML, CSS, and JS" with ECMAScript 3, allowing developers to "automate in-app workflows."

## Core Capabilities

Plugin developers can create functionality across multiple domains:
- Automate intricate workflows
- Interface with external hardware devices
- Add support for additional file formats and codecs
- Design custom effects and transitions
- Build panels that integrate naturally into the editing interface

## Technical Languages Supported

- HTML/CSS/JavaScript (UXP and CEP)
- C++ (SDK-based development)
- ECMAScript 3 (CEP legacy support)

## Resource Access

Developers encountering access restrictions when downloading the C++ SDK should attempt logging in using a Personal account rather than an organizational one.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Adobe Exchange plugin certification review process requirements:

## Adobe Exchange Plugin Review Process

To publish on Adobe's Marketplaces, your plugin must first go through a review process. By reviewing every plugin, Adobe aims to help developers get ready for prime time and ensure that users have great experiences with the plugins they consume.(no content)Adobe's goal is to balance providing developers with the best developer experience during the review process as possible, while also ensuring the approved plugins offer a great user experience for their mutual customers.

### Key Requirements

#### Publisher Profile Requirements
You need to provide your publisher marketing website (which shows for all things you publish with Adobe and should be scoped to you as the publisher), along with a description of you, the publisher.

#### EU Distribution Requirements
In accordance with the European Union Digital Services Act trader requirements, developers who wish to distribute their listings in the EU must provide additional information in their publisher profile. Any developer who wishes to distribute their listings in the EU can be identified as a trader. Developers must choose "Yes" if they wish to make their listings available in Adobe Exchange Marketplace for users in the European Union.

#### Plugin Packaging Requirements
For a hybrid extension, the folder must include the resource files for the native plugin or scripting component. A file named "mimetype" will be generated by the signing process, which is detailed in the guide for packaging and signing your CEP plugins.(no content)MXI packaging is used for more generically formed packages. With an MXI, you can include multiple ZXP containing extensions and also include files to be placed anywhere on the user's system. You need to add manifest details such as a unique bundle id and versions for Adobe products that your app supports in a .mxi file, and the .mxi file should have the name that matches the bundle id of your extension.

#### Paid Plugin Requirements
For paid plugin listings, you'll need to register with Adobe's third-party payment provider, FastSpring, and enter your FastSpring key into your publisher profile. It may take up to 24 hours for FastSpring to create your key.

#### Listing Metadata
Your listing metadata provides Adobe and users with details about the plugin you are currently submitting. The information you add will be made public to users via Adobe's Marketplace surfaces once your listing is published.

### Preparation Tips
The Adobe submission guides are meant to provide developers with an idea of what types of information they will need for the submission process and how to best prepare for review. Working through the guides helps ensure you've accounted for all of the requirements so you can avoid having to fix things and resubmit before being published.

Based on my search, here's comprehensive information about Adobe Premiere Pro C++ SDK development for video effects and transition plugins:

## Adobe Premiere Pro C++ SDK for Video Effects & Transition Plugin Development

### Official SDK Resources

The Adobe Premiere Pro Software Development Kit is a living document that is constantly being updated and edited. The latest release of the SDK is available at: https://www.adobe.io/apis/creativecloud/premierepro.html

### Plugin Types Available

The Premiere Pro SDK supports several plugin types including:
- Video Effects Plugins – Custom filters, LUTs, and overlays
- Transition Plugins – Custom wipe, dissolve, and animation transitions
- Audio Effects Plugins – EQ, noise reduction, and AI-powered enhancements
- File Import & Export Automation – Batch processing for video files(no content)There are two main plugin development approaches:
- CEP Extensions (Common Extensibility Platform) – Built using HTML, JavaScript, and CSS for UI-based plugins
- Native Plugins (C++ SDK) – Built using C++ for deeper integration with video processing

### Getting Started with Transition Development

If you are developing a transition, begin with the SDK_CrossDissolve sample project, progressively replacing its functionality with your own. The sample project is also dependent on the After Effects SDK.(no content)On Windows, create an environment variable pointing to it named "AE_SDK_BASE_PATH", so that the compiler will find the AE headers. On MacOS, in XCode > Preferences > Locations > Custom Paths, specify AE_SDK_BASE_PATH to be the root folder of the AE SDK.

### GPU Effects & Transitions

The GPU extensions allow plugins to have full access to GPU-resident frames without readback to system memory, when using the Mercury Playback Engine in a GPU-accelerated mode.(no content)Effects and transitions can optionally tell the host that they support real-time processing. The GPU extensions work on top of effects and transitions built using the After Effects SDK, supplementing a regular software effect or transition which defines the software rendering path, parameters, and custom UI drawing.

### System Requirements for GPU Development

The system requirements for developing GPU effects & transitions are higher than developing other plugins. You'll need a video card that supports Mercury Playback Engine GPU acceleration and must ensure your video card supports the type of video acceleration you are developing.(no content)To compile GPU effects in Premiere SDK, Adobe highly recommends using CUDA SDK 11.8. The minimum CUDA Compute Capability has been increased to sm_50.(no content)For best compatibility, Adobe recommends utilizing CUDA Driver API only. Unlike the runtime API, the driver API is directly backwards compatible with future drivers.

### Recent SDK Updates

Multiple effects and transitions can now be implemented in a single plugin binary, by defining multiple entry points in software at runtime. This new method for registering entry points will be a replacement for the PiPL resource.(no content)AE-style Transitions can now get and set transition start and end percentages. To allow a plugin to be informed of changes to these values, there are functions in the PF TransitionSuite: RegisterTransitionStartParam() and RegisterTransitionEndParam().

### C++ SDK Status

The C++ SDK is complete and used without issue by C++ plugin developers. The C++ SDK does not contain any CEP or UXP resources.(no content)Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK and may need the Premiere Pro headers, available at the Adobe Developer portal.

content.content:
# Premiere Pro ExtendScript API Capabilities

## Overview
The Premiere Pro ExtendScript API provides comprehensive control over the application. According to the documentation, "ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options."

## Object Model Structure

The API is organized into several key categories:

**Core Objects:**
- Application and Project management
- Sequences and Tracks for timeline access
- ProjectItems and TrackItems for clip manipulation
- Collections for managing groups of objects

**Functional Areas:**

1. **Project Manipulation**: The Project object and ProjectCollection enable working with project files and their contents.

2. **Sequence/Timeline Access**: Sequence, Track, and TrackCollection objects provide timeline control. Component and ComponentParam objects manage effects and properties.

3. **Clip Manipulation**: TrackItem and ProjectItem objects handle individual clips, while TrackItemCollection manages multiple clips.

4. **Import/Export Functions**: The Encoder object supports rendering and exporting operations, complemented by the ProjectManager for project-level tasks.

5. **Additional Capabilities**: 
   - Marker and MarkerCollection objects for annotation
   - Metadata object for information management
   - AudioChannelMapping for audio configuration
   - Time object for temporal operations

## Important Note
As of November 2025, Adobe has transitioned to UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) for new integrations, though ExtendScript remains supported through September 2026.

# Premiere Pro C++ SDK Overview

Based on the documentation structure, here's what the SDK encompasses:

## Plugin Types Supported

The SDK enables development of multiple plugin categories:
- **Importers** - for importing media formats
- **Exporters** - for exporting to various formats
- **Video Filters** - standard video processing effects
- **GPU Effects & Transitions** - hardware-accelerated processing using CUDA, OpenCL, Metal, or OpenGL
- **Transmitters** - for streaming and transmission
- **Control Surfaces** - for hardware controller integration
- **AE Transition Extensions** - After Effects transition compatibility

## Core Capabilities

The documentation indicates the SDK provides:
- "Time," "Video Frames," "Pixel Formats And Color Spaces," pixel aspect ratio, and fields management
- Audio processing capabilities
- Memory management systems
- Basic type structures and suites for API interactions
- Hardware integration components with ClassID and subtype definitions

## Development Framework

The SDK includes:
- Selector-based function tables for plugin communication
- Return code systems for error handling
- Structure definitions for data exchange
- Suite systems for accessing Premiere Pro functionality
- Debugging plugin support resources

## Documentation Access

The guide references the official SDK availability at Adobe's developer portal and maintains an active "Premiere Pro SDK forum" for developer support and questions.

input.prompt: Extract all information about plugin submission requirements, review process, certification requirements, and distribution guidelines for Adobe Creative Cloud plugins

content.content:
# Adobe Creative Cloud Plugin Submission Requirements

## Review Process Overview

Adobe requires all plugins to undergo a review process before marketplace publication. The stated goal is to "balance providing you with the best developer experience during the review process as possible, while also ensuring the approved plugins offer a great user experience."

## Publisher Profile Requirements

Before submitting any plugin, developers must establish and approve a publisher profile containing:

- Public company or personal name
- Marketing website (applicable to all your Adobe publications)
- Publisher description and logo
- Trader details (for EU distribution)

**Key deadline:** EU traders must submit details by "February 16, 2025, to keep your plugin visible and available for users in the European Union as of February 17, 2025."

## EU Trader Requirements

Per the European Union Digital Services Act, developers distributing in the EU must provide:
- Business email and phone number
- Complete business address
- Country information
- D-U-N-S number (optional)

This information becomes publicly visible on listing pages accessed from EU countries.

## Listing & Version Metadata

Submissions require:
- Plugin name, subtitle, and description (with localization options)
- Support contact and help documentation URLs
- Three icon sizes and promotional screenshots/videos
- Category tags and service policies (privacy, terms of service)
- Release notes for each version

## Plugin Package Requirements

**UXP plugins:** Compress contents (not parent folder) as `.zip`, rename to `.xdx` (XD) or `.ccx` (Photoshop)

**ZXP/CEP plugins:** Package with CSXS folder containing `manifest.xml`, sign using Adobe's `ZXPSignCmd` tool

**Non-plugin files:** Submit as `.zip` archives

## Payment Processing

Paid plugins require FastSpring registration with account key entry into the publisher profile (up to 24-hour processing time).

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP scripting API for timeline clip manipulation with modern JavaScript:

## Premiere Pro UXP Scripting API Overview

### Current Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro. This moment has been long-awaited by Premiere plugin developers since UXP was originally announced by Adobe back in 2019.

### What is UXP?

UXP plugins panels are the new way for 3rd party developers to build plugin panels in Adobe applications in JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.(no content)UXP Plugins are JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, however they are built on their own unique stack by Adobe which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Additionally instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for your frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.

### Timeline and Clip Manipulation Capabilities

The UXP API allows access to sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous and blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Recent API Updates

Adobe has announced updates for UXP APIs available in recent versions of Premiere Pro (Beta), including ClipProjectItem API which allows for attaching proxy or high resolution footage or replacing footage with `attachProxy()` and `changeMediaPath()`, as well as EncoderManager and SequenceEditor APIs.

### Getting Selection and Events

The API includes a `getSelection()` method that returns currently-selected clips as an Array of TrackItems, which works perfectly. Combined with `app.bind`, developers are able to get real-time events of what the selected item is set to.

### Limitations

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks, meaning even UI automation cannot rely on a universal shortcut.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items.

### Development Resources

The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.(no content)There are sample plugins available to help develop UXP plugins within Premiere Pro. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins.

### Recommendation for Developers

It's highly recommended to start looking at all of the Premiere Pro APIs your current extensions use (e.g., importing footage, adding clips to the timeline, exporting, etc.) and test if those features exist and work as you need them to in UXP.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro CEP panel development and the PProPanel sample on GitHub:

## Adobe-CEP/Samples - PProPanel

The PProPanel sample project is exhaustive in its exercise of Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API. The main repository is available at **[Adobe-CEP/Samples](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples)** on GitHub.

### Key Resources:

1. **Main Repository**: Code samples for CEP extensions. Contribute to Adobe-CEP/Samples development by creating an account on GitHub.

2. **Development Environment**: Microsoft Visual Studio Code, and the ExtendScript debugging extension. This extension running in VSCode is Adobe's recommended ExtendScript development environment.

### Installation Locations:

Put /PProPanel or your own panel's containing directory here, to have Premiere Pro load it:
- **Windows**: `C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\Adobe\CEP\extensions`
- **Mac**: `/Library/Application Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions`

### Enabling Debug Mode for Unsigned Panels:

Premiere Pro 23.x integrates CEP11, so even if you had unsigned panels loading before (up to CEP10), you'll need to perform this step again, but for key CSXS.11.(no content)On MacOS, type the following into Terminal, then relaunch Finder: `defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1`

### Signing and Distribution:

To sign directory /PanelDir with certificate.p12, do the following: `./ZXPSignCmd -sign panelDir/ PanelName.zxp certificate.p12 password -tsa http://timestamp.digicert.com/`(no content)You can also directly supply the .zxp file enterprise customers, and those who do not connect their systems to the public internet, for installation using UPIA, the command line version of Extension Manager.

### TypeScript Version:

There's also a TypeScript version available at **[Samples/TypeScript/PProPanel-vscode](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/TypeScript/PProPanel-vscode)**. The PProPanel sample project is exhaustive in its exercise of Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API. The ZXPSignCmd signing utility creates signed .zxp bundles for Add-Ons or direct distribution.

### Additional Information:

The provided samples are unsigned. This will cause the signature check (built into CEP when first running an extension) to fail. To bypass the signature check, please refer to the documentation.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.text:
Based on my comprehensive research, here is a detailed guide to Adobe Premiere Pro plugin development for 2024/2025:

---

# Adobe Premiere Pro Plugin Development Guide (2024-2025)

**Documented for:** Premiere Pro v25.x (2025), with backwards compatibility to v24.x (2024)

---

## 1. Adobe Premiere Pro SDK Overview

Adobe provides multiple development pathways for Premiere Pro plugins, each suited to different use cases:

### Plugin Types You Can Build

| Type | Technology | Use Case |
|------|------------|----------|
| **UXP Plugins** | HTML/CSS/JavaScript | Modern panel development (recommended for new projects) |
| **CEP Extensions** | HTML/CSS/JavaScript + ExtendScript | Legacy panel development |
| **C++ Native Plugins** | C++ | Video effects, transitions, importers/exporters, hardware integration |

### C++ SDK Capabilities

The C++ SDK enables deep system integration for:
- **Video Filters** - Custom effects and color processing
- **GPU Effects & Transitions** - Hardware-accelerated processing using CUDA, OpenCL, Metal, or OpenGL
- **Importers** - Support for additional media formats
- **Exporters** - Custom encoding/output formats
- **Transmitters** - Streaming and broadcast output
- **Control Surfaces** - Hardware controller integration
- **Audio Processing** - Custom audio effects

**System Requirements for GPU Development:**
- CUDA SDK 11.8 (recommended)
- Minimum CUDA Compute Capability: sm_50
- Video card supporting Mercury Playback Engine GPU acceleration

---

## 2. Languages and Frameworks

### UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) - The Modern Standard

**Status:** As of December 2024, UXP entered public beta for Premiere Pro. Full support is available in Premiere Pro v25.6+.

```
Languages: HTML5, CSS3, Modern JavaScript (ES6+)
Architecture: Single unified environment (no ExtendScript backend)
Performance: Lightweight stack (no Node.js or Chromium)
```

**Key Advantages:**
- Asynchronous API calls that do not block the UI thread
- Modern JavaScript instead of ECMAScript 3
- Better performance than CEP
- Single codebase for UI and host API calls

### CEP (Common Extensibility Platform) - Legacy but Still Supported

```
Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript (frontend) + ExtendScript (backend)
CEP Version: CEP 11 (Premiere Pro 23.x+) / CEP 12 (current)
ECMAScript: Version 3 (legacy)
```

**Note:** ExtendScript-based integrations remain supported through **September 2026**, but no further API improvements are planned.

### C++ SDK

```
IDE: Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 Update 3 (Windows)
     Xcode (macOS)
Dependencies: After Effects SDK headers (for effects/transitions)
```

---

## 3. Creating Panels and UI

### UXP Panel Development (Recommended)

UXP panels use modern web technologies with Adobe's custom runtime:

```javascript
// UXP plugin example structure
const { app } = require("premiere");

// Get current project
const project = app.project;

// Access sequences
const sequences = project.sequences;
```

**Key Resources:**
- [Premiere Pro UXP API Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [UXP Sample Plugins](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)

### CEP Panel Development

**Installation Locations:**
```
Windows: C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\Adobe\CEP\extensions
macOS: /Library/Application Support/Adobe/CEP/extensions
```

**Enable Debug Mode (for unsigned panels):**
```bash
# macOS (CEP 12)
defaults write /Users/<username>/Library/Preferences/com.adobe.CSXS.12.plist PlayerDebugMode 1

# Windows (run as Administrator in PowerShell)
reg add "HKCU\Software\Adobe\CSXS.12" /v PlayerDebugMode /t REG_SZ /d 1
```

**Reference Sample:** The [PProPanel](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel) sample is Adobe's comprehensive reference implementation demonstrating all ExtendScript API capabilities.

---

## 4. Timeline and Clip Manipulation

### ExtendScript API (CEP)

The ExtendScript API provides access to:
- **Project** and **ProjectCollection** - Project management
- **Sequence** and **Track** - Timeline access
- **TrackItem** and **ProjectItem** - Clip manipulation
- **Marker** and **MarkerCollection** - Annotations
- **Encoder** - Export operations

**Example - Inserting clips into a sequence:**
```javascript
// ExtendScript example
var project = app.project;
var sequence = project.activeSequence;
var rootItem = project.rootItem;

// Insert clip at playhead position
var clipToInsert = rootItem.children[0]; // First item in project
var targetTime = sequence.getPlayerPosition();
sequence.videoTracks[0].insertClip(clipToInsert, targetTime);
```

### UXP API

UXP provides similar capabilities with async/await patterns:

```javascript
// UXP example
const { app } = require("premiere");

async function getSelectedClips() {
    const selection = await app.project.activeSequence.getSelection();
    return selection; // Returns Array of TrackItems
}
```

**Available UXP APIs (as of late 2024):**
- `getSelection()` - Get selected clips
- `ClipProjectItem` - Attach proxy/replace footage via `attachProxy()` and `changeMediaPath()`
- `EncoderManager` - Export operations
- `SequenceEditor` - Timeline manipulation

### Known Limitations

- **No vertical clip movement:** There is no API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) to move clips between tracks
- **No single clip split call:** Splitting clips at playhead requires workarounds
- **Async nature in UXP:** All method calls are asynchronous (properties remain synchronous)

---

## 5. Import/Export and Metadata

### Media Import

```javascript
// ExtendScript - Import media
var importArray = ["C:/path/to/video.mp4"];
app.project.importFiles(importArray);

// Import with specific settings
app.project.importFiles(importArray, 
    suppressUI,           // boolean
    targetBin,            // ProjectItem
    importAsNumberedStills // boolean
);
```

### Export/Encoding

```javascript
// ExtendScript - Export sequence
var sequence = app.project.activeSequence;
var outputPath = "C:/output/exported.mp4";
var presetPath = "C:/path/to/preset.epr";

app.encoder.encodeSequence(
    sequence,
    outputPath,
    presetPath,
    app.encoder.ENCODE_WORKAREA,  // or ENCODE_IN_TO_OUT, ENCODE_ENTIRE
    true  // Remove from queue upon completion
);
```

### Metadata Access

Premiere Pro uses XMP (Extensible Metadata Platform) for metadata:

```javascript
// Get project item metadata
var projectItem = app.project.rootItem.children[0];
var metadata = projectItem.getProjectMetadata();

// Set custom metadata
projectItem.setProjectMetadata(
    "Custom Value",
    ["Column.PropertyText.Custom Field"]
);

// Get XMP metadata
var xmpMetadata = projectItem.getXMPMetadata();
```

**Key Metadata Methods:**
- `getProjectMetadata()` / `setProjectMetadata()` - Project-level metadata
- `getXMPMetadata()` / `setXMPMetadata()` - Source file XMP metadata
- Private metadata via Adobe-CEP APIs (project-item specific)

**Limitation:** Adobe Media Encoder offers no APIs for sequence manipulation. For export metadata, you may need to re-import the exported file, modify metadata, save, then remove from project.

---

## 6. Plugin Distribution Requirements

### Adobe Exchange Marketplace

To distribute on Adobe Exchange:

#### Publisher Profile Requirements
- Company/personal name
- Marketing website and description
- Publisher logo
- **EU Traders:** Must provide business details per the EU Digital Services Act (deadline was February 17, 2025)

#### Plugin Package Requirements

**UXP Plugins:**
```
1. Compress contents (not parent folder) as .zip
2. Rename extension to .ccx (for Premiere Pro)
```

**CEP/ZXP Plugins:**
```
1. Include CSXS folder with manifest.xml
2. Sign using ZXPSignCmd tool
```

**Signing Command:**
```bash
./ZXPSignCmd -sign panelDir/ PanelName.zxp certificate.p12 password -tsa http://timestamp.digicert.com/
```

#### Paid Plugin Requirements
- Register with FastSpring (Adobe's payment processor)
- Enter FastSpring key in publisher profile
- Processing time: up to 24 hours

### Direct Distribution

For enterprise or offline distribution:
- Provide signed `.zxp` files directly
- Users install via UPIA (command-line Extension Manager)
- Code signing certificates required:
  - **macOS:** Apple Developer ID certificate + notarization
  - **Windows:** Code signing certificate from trusted CA

---

## Quick Reference: Development Path Decision Tree

```
Need custom video effects/transitions/codecs?
  └─> C++ SDK

Need a panel UI for automation/workflow?
  ├─> Starting new project (2024+)?
  │     └─> UXP (modern JavaScript)
  └─> Maintaining existing project?
        └─> CEP + ExtendScript (supported through Sept 2026)
```

---

## Key Resources

| Resource | URL |
|----------|-----|
| Official Developer Portal | https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/ |
| C++ SDK Guide | https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/ |
| ExtendScript Scripting Guide | https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/ |
| UXP API Reference | https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ |
| CEP Samples (PProPanel) | https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel |
| UXP Samples | https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples |
| SDK Forum | https://community.adobe.com/t5/forums/filteredbylabelpage/board-id/premiere-pro/label-name/sdk |
| Submission Guide | https://developer.adobe.com/developer-distribution/creative-cloud/docs/guides/submission/overview |

---

## Important Notes

1. **UXP is the future:** Adobe recommends UXP for all new development. Test your required APIs in UXP before starting a new CEP project.

2. **ExtendScript sunset:** No further improvements planned; supported through September 2026.

3. **SDK access:** If you get "Restricted Access" when downloading the C++ SDK, try logging in with a Personal Adobe account rather than an organizational one.

4. **Development environment:** VSCode with the ExtendScript Debugger extension is Adobe's recommended setup for CEP development.

---

**Sources:**

- [Adobe Premiere Pro Developer Portal](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/)
- [Premiere Pro C++ SDK Guide](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/)
- [Premiere Pro Scripting Guide](https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/)
- [Adobe-CEP/Samples GitHub Repository](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples)
- [Adobe Developer Distribution - Submission Overview](https://developer.adobe.com/developer-distribution/creative-cloud/docs/guides/submission/overview)
- [Hyper Brew - Premiere Pro UXP Beta](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/premiere-pro-uxp-beta/)
- [GPU Effects & Transitions Documentation](https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/gpu-effects-transitions/gpu-effects-transitions/)
- [MetaDesign Solutions - Premiere Pro Plugin Development](https://metadesignsolutions.com/developing-adobe-premiere-pro-plugins-using-adobe-premiere-pro-sdk-with-code/)
- [Creative Cloud Developer Forums - UXP Updates](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/update-of-uxp-apis-inside-of-premiere-pro/10384)
